attributes.title: Laminar fMRI at 3T: A replication attempt of top-down and bottom-up laminar activity in the early visual cortex

q1.value: Laminar fMRI at 3T: A replication attempt of top-down and bottom-up laminar activity in the early visual cortex

q2.value: Jonas Karolis Degutis, Benedikt Valerian Ehinger, Floris de Lange

q3.value:
A growing body of fMRI research has tried disassociating bottom-up and top-down signals by looking at the laminar profiles within individual regions such as the primary sensory cortices (Kok, Bains, van Mourik, Norris, & de Lange, 2016; Lawrence et al., 2018). Most of the research has used “ultra-high field” MRI of 7T and above which has the capacity to increase the SNR of the acquired images, thus enabling independent measures of the BOLD signal at different depths of the neocortex. Each depth has dominant functions and connections associated with it.
For example, the primary visual cortex consists of six histological layers. Previous research methods have been able to divide the cortex into three gray-matter depths. The BOLD signals within the superficial and deep depths is associated with feedback, while activity in the middle depth is feedforward processes (Lawrence, Norris, & de Lange, 2019). Recent work from the de Lange lab has shown differing laminar profiles between contrast effects (a bottom-up manipulation) and attention effects (top-down) in the early visual cortex (V1-V3). During the contrast manipulation, granular layers were more active, while during the attention task agranuar layers showed higher activity. Furthermore, Lawrence et al. (2018) also found increased activity in the superficial and deep layers in comparison to the middle layer during the maintenance period of a visual working memory task.

q4.value:
1)	Replication: Can earlier reported bottom-up and top-down laminar profiles be replicated on a 3T scanner?
a)	Specifically, will the activation of agranular compared to granular layers be higher during the working memory period (thus replicating the top-down effect).
b)	Will the activation of granular compared to agranular be larger for the higher contrast stimulus compared to the lower contrast (thus replicating the bottom-up effect)?
2)	Novel: Is there a correlation between the layer-dependent WM effect (agranular subtracted by granular) and the WM accuracy of the participants (measured by a stair-case)?
a)	Is there a correlation between the WM effect and the vividness of an individual’s imagery (measured using the Vividness of Visual Imagery Questionnaire)?

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Design type: slow event related design for WM (top-down) task and block design for contrast task (bottom-up).

Conditions and stimuli:
The participants will perform a visual working memory retro-cue experiment both during the psychophysics session and within the scanner. The subjects will be presented with two Gabor patches of different orientations (on for 0.2 seconds each with a 0.4s interstimulus interval) followed by a cue (0.8s) indicating which orientation to remember. After the stimuli, a delay period (10.7s) will follow during which the participants have to maintain the remembered orientation. A probe stimulus (0.5s) will be presented after the delay period following which the subjects have to indicate (2 seconds time window for response) whether the orientation of the probe stimulus was shifted clockwise or counter-clockwise compared to the remembered orientation. A feedback screen (0.3s) will be presented indicating whether the answer was correct. Grating stimuli will be presented centrally at 50% contrast on a gray background behind an ever present fixation annulus mask (outer radius 8°, inner radius 1°). The edges of the Gabors will be softened using a linear ramp that started 0.5mm from the edge. In each trial the sample gratings that will be presented will be nearly orthogonal to one another (45° ± 3, 135° ± 3°). Each trial will be 25.6s long with an ITI of 10s. One run will last for 521.6s. 
For the contrast task the participants will be presented with oriented gratings (same parameters as the working memory task, except for contrast; to be discussed later) in a AoBo block design. The stimulus will be presented for 13.6 seconds (4 TRs) followed by rest blocks of the same length. The Gabors will be presented at a frequency of 2 Hz (250ms on 250ms off). The blocks will alter between 45° and 135°. The participant will have to pay attention to a fixation annulus (same parameters as in the WM task) presented in the middle of the Gabor and indicate when it flashes (one to four flashes per stimulus block) using a button box. The phase will be randomized for each presented stimulus. One contrast run will consist of 30 stimulus blocks (15 for each orientation). The total length of one run will be 828.8 s. In total there will be two contrast runs per participant: 30% and 80% contrast gratings. The initial contrast block will also be determined randomly.
Both the working memory and contrast are programmed in MATLAB version 2016b (MathWorks, Natrick, MA) and presented using PsychToolbox.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Two subjects have already done the experiment; the data has not been analyzed or looked at.

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through the Radboud Research Participation System (Radboud SONA), which primarily consists of students from Radboud University and HAN University of Applied Sciences.
Participant inclusion criteria: normal or corrected vision, right-handedness, MRI compatible, no history of epilepsy or cardiac problems. If the participant’s WM accuracy after the behavioral psychophysics sessions is below 30°, he/she will be excluded for the MRI experiment (details to follow).  
Payment: the participants will be paid 8€/hour for the behavioral session and 10€/hour for MRI session.
IRB and consent: all participants will provide informed consent. The study was approved by the local ethics committee (CMO region Arnhem-Nijmegen, the Netherlands).
Number of participants: 55+5 for fMRI. 55+10 for behavioral. 
Age: only participants above the age of 18 will be recruited.
Sex: male and female
Handedness: right
Study timeline: each participant will complete an hour of a behavioral psychophysics task and a questionnaire and two hours of MRI.

q13.value:
We will aim to recruit up to 60 healthy human participants. Two approaches were used to determine the sample size: frequentist approach based on power-contours, which take both the amount of trials and the amount of subjects into account, Bayesian approach using a sequential t-test on the aggregated data.
The frequentist sample size of 60 was calculated to achieve a power of 80% to detect a between-subject effect size of 0.8 based on an a priori calculation using the within- (0.427) and between-subject variances (0.0436) estimated from Lawrence et al 2018 dataset for the working memory effect (agranular-granular). Because we record fMRI at 3T and not 7T, we multiplied our within-subject variance estimate for the power estimation by two, thus accounting for the decreased SNR when going to a lower field magnet. 
We will use sequential Bayesian testing in order to make the best use of our limited resources. We use a Bayesian t-test with a Cauchy prior on the effect size of the difference of agranular-granular, (scaling factor of 0.707, so that 70% of effect sizes occur are expected between -1.5 and 1.5). Sequential testing analysis using the BFDA package shows that (assuming an effect size with mean 0.8, sd 0.4) 93% of experiments would end with a BF>6 for the alternative hypothesis before our n-max of 60. Sampling from no effect, we find that 77% of studies would finish with conclusive evidence for H0. We think this is a  well powered study. We want to note that there is considerable uncertainty on the between subject effect size (indicated by a very large standard deviation), given that it is unclear how much signal-decrease we should expect from going from 7T to 3T, as physiological noise dominates when averaging over large areas of cortex.

Our bayes factor sequential sampling analysis conforms with the frequentist power-contour analysis and consequently we think this is a sensible sampling plan.

question.value:
Measured Behavioral Variables:

The aim of the behavioral session is to measure the WM accuracy of a participant. After each trial, the participant’s response (clockwise or counter-clockwise) will be recorded and compared to the actual rotation of the presented probe relative to the remembered orientation. A QUEST staircase function will be used calibrate their performance to 75% accuracy by adjusting the difference between the remembered orientation and the probe (i.e. the orientation difference in degrees; the smaller the difference between the two, the more difficult the task, since it is harder to determine whether the probe has rotated clockwise or counter-clockwise).

The orientation difference determined during the behavioral session plus an additional 25% increment (e.g. 5°+1.25°) will then be used as the initial value for the QUEST staircase within the scanner (which will then be adjusted after every trial).
The average orientation difference across all MRI trials will be used for the correlation analysis.

fMRI BOLD data acquisition: 

All MRI data will be acquired using a 3T PrismaFit Siemens scanner. 
0.8mm 3D gradient Echo EPI with 4 x 2 acceleration and partial-fourier.

 Preprocessing:
-       Cropping of functional and anatomical volumes so that only the occipital lobe remain, which helps with the alignment of anatomy to the functional EPI
-       Spatially realigned within and then between runs using SPM (quality 1, interpolation 4, fwhm 1mm, sep 1, rtm 1 
-       Data will be high-pass filtered using FEAT (to remove MRI drift)

Working Memory Activity Measurement:
A univariate approach described by Albers et al (2018) will be used to measure the working memory activity within V1. The time courses of each depth will be separated into eight volumes each, corresponding to the eight TRs within a trial. For each trial, the ‘preferred’ trial time course will be determined based on which orientation the participant remembers (e.g. 45° is preferred if the participant will have to remember the clockwise orientation). Each trial will also be used for the non-preferred time course, which will consist of the activation of voxels of the opposite orientation to the one that was remembered (e.g. 135° is non-preferred if the participant will have to remember the clockwise orientation). This division will be done for every single trial, resulting in the same number of preferred and non-preferred time courses (each having the same number of 45° and 135° as the preferred orientation).
We will only look at the activity within the two delay period TRs (TR number 3 and 4). First, the activity will be averaged across and then we will subtract the activity of the preferred orientation voxels (the orientation that was remembered) by the non-preferred orientation voxels (the orientation that was not remembered) in each trial.
A filter will be used to weight the functional data from each voxel by their orientation preference using a matrix of t-values indicative of each voxel’s preference (described in the ‘Functional Masks’ section). The data from clockwise-preferring voxels will be multiplied by the clockwise>counter-clockwise t-values, while the data from the counter-clockwise voxels will be multiplied using the opposite contrast’s t-values.

Contrast Activity Measurement:
The contrast task will also be used to determine the bottom-up laminar activity within V1. The activity within four TRs (2nd-5th) of the plateaued BOLD signal will be used to calculate the bottom-up activity. The average high contrast response will be subtracted from the low contrast averaged activity for each layer. The effect will be measured on V1 as a whole. 
  
Statistical Analyses:
The sequential Bayesian t-test described above will directly test the effect of agranular vs. granular activation. We will perform the same test for the contrast activity condition. These will be the main results of the study.
In addition we will be using Bayesian linear mixed models (LMMs) to estimate uncertainties and effect sizes. We will make use of the following weakly informed priors:
Fixed effects: student-t df=3, mean=0, sd = 0.1
Random effects: 0-truncated student-t, df=3, mean=0, sd=0.1
Residual SD: 0-truncated student_t df=3, mean=0, sd=0.1.
These reflect the expected effect sizes after aggregating over trials.
 For the working memory results, we subtract data of preferred-non preferred and aggregate over trials. We then use a 1x3 design to test for overall activation and individual layer effects within V1. We will report coefficient effect estimates and credibility intervals.
The same statistical approach will be used for the contrast effect. 
Similar to Lawrence 2019, will additionally test whether there is a difference between the laminar activation during the working memory task (top-down) and the activation during the contrast task (bottom-up). A two by three repeated measures LMM (factors: task and depth) will be used to determine whether there is an interaction between bottom-up and top-down laminar activity within V1.

q24.value: The average working memory effect of each participant (agranular subtracted by granular activation) will be correlated with the individual’s average working memory accuracy value within the scanner (determined using QUEST). We will use a robust skipped pearson correlation for this. Furthermore, the individual average working memory effects will also be correlated with individual scores obtained from the Vividness of Visual Imagery Questionnaire (VVIQ).

q25.value:
Functional Masks:
We will consider only one region of interest (ROI): V1. This will be defined using a probabilistic atlas (neuropythy package).
Following the delineation of the ROI, the average of the two contrast runs will be used to define the orientation-specificity of each voxel within V1. Clockwise (45°) and counter-clockwise (135°) regressors will be contrasted against one another for both contrast runs, which will provide a t-statistic for each voxel’s orientation preference as the average of the 30% and 80% contrasts runs. We will use FSLs FEAT on the previously aligned localizer data. 500 voxels with the most positive t-values (clockwise preference) and 500 voxels with the most negative t-values (counter-clockwise preference) will be used to form separate functional maps within V1. For each subject there will be two functional masks containing 500 voxels each. Following Lawrence et al. we will then weigh the main task functional BOLD timecourses by the independent functional t-value, effectively allowing for a weighted functional mask.

Segmentation and alignment of laminar surfaces:
-       Segmentation of full anatomical via Freesurfer’s recon-all
-       First alignment of full anatomical to cropped functional via cropped anatomical
-       Bias correction of the mean functional image using fast (fast -t 2 -n 2 -H 0.1 -I 4 -l 20.0 --nopve -B)
-       SPM BBR method to align surfaces to cropped functional data
-       Recurrent boundary registration algorithm (open fMRI toolbox, accuracy 30, nIterations 6)
Estimation of Laminar Activity:
Depth-specific time courses will be estimated using the Open fMRI Toolbox by van Mourik et al. (2018) (same parameters as in Lawrence 2018). Freesurfer will be used to segment the cortical mesh into five separate depth bins: white matter, three equivolume gray matter bins, and CSF. A matrix of depth weights will be created indicative of the proportion of overlap between each voxel and the five separate depth bins. These weights will then be regressed against the functional data from each of the voxels to produce a single time course for each depth. This will be done separately for the clockwise and counter-clockwise orientation preferring masks and for V1 as a whole.

The average high contrast response will be subtracted from the low contrast averaged activity for each layer. The effect will be measured on V1 as a whole.

The sequential Bayesian t-test described above will directly test the effect of agranular vs. granular activation. We will perform the same test for the contrast activity condition. These will be the main results of the study.
In addition we will be using Bayesian linear mixed models (LMMs) to estimate uncertainties and effect sizes. We will make use of the following weakly informed priors:
Fixed effects: student-t df=3, mean=0, sd = 0.1
Random effects: 0-truncated student-t, df=3, mean=0, sd=0.1
Residual SD: 0-truncated student_t df=3, mean=0, sd=0.1.
These reflect the expected effect sizes after aggregating over trials.
 For the working memory results, we subtract data of preferred-non preferred and aggregate over trials. We then use a 1x3 design to test for overall activation and individual layer effects within V1. We will report coefficient effect estimates and credibility intervals.
The same statistical approach will be used for the contrast effect. 
Similar to Lawrence 2019, will additionally test whether there is a difference between the laminar activation during the working memory task (top-down) and the activation during the contrast task (bottom-up). A two by three repeated measures LMM (factors: task and depth) will be used to determine whether there is an interaction between bottom-up and top-down laminar activity within V1.

attributes.title: Social Norms and Climate Policy Support

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Informational Social Influence on Climate Policy Support

other.value: Manipulation checks will be collected measuring perceptions of how well oneself, partisan peers, and partisan experts understand the climate policy, as well as perceptions of party norms in support or opposition for the policy. Additional potential moderators will be collected for exploratory analyses including perceptions of how biased and informed partisan peers and experts are, how surprised participants were about partisan stances towards the policy, how much participants anticipate positive or negative social consequences from expressing viewpoints in support of or in opposition to the policy, and how much participants think factors including one's own knowledge and values and each party's knowledge and values should weigh into policy evaluation. Demographics will also be collected.

sample.value:
We collected 300 participants already based on a power analysis to achieve 80% power for the effect of social norms on climate policy support. This power analysis was based on an effect size found in our previous work. 

In our replication of the Informational Influence Pilot Study, we found null results for the moderation of norms by expert understanding of the policy for Democrats and we seek to draw a conclusion that the null hypothesis is more likely than the alternative; thus, we will increase the sample size to 200 to reach a Bayes factor of at least 3 for the comparison between the null and alternative hypotheses (Schoenbrodt et al., 2017).

analyses.value: We will conduct a 2x2x2 ANOVA for the effects of norms (ingroup party supports or opposes the policy), partisan expert understanding (ingroup experts understand the climate policy or do not), and political party on climate policy support. We will then calculate a Bayes factor for the moderation of the effect of norms by understanding for both parties.

outliers.value: Because our dependent variable is measured on a 7-point Likert scale, we will not have outliers. We will exclude observations for which participants gave nonsense responses or responses in all capital letters to open-ended questions in order to ensure data quality from Amazon MTurk (Chmielewski & Kucker, 2019).

dependent.value: The key dependent variable is support for climate policy. We measure this through responses on 7-point Likert scales ranging from strongly oppose to strongly support to two questions: (1)  "To what extent do you support or oppose a bill to impose a carbon tax on businesses?" and (2) "How much would you personally support enactment of a policy along these lines in the United States in the near future?"

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned into one of four conditions. We will cross expert understanding of the policy (experts in one's own political party either understand or do not understand the climate policy) with partisan norms (peers in one's own party either support or oppose the policy).

hypothesis.value: We already replicated the study run as a pilot study in the previous preregistration (Informational Influence Pilot Study) and are preregistering additional data collection. We test the hypothesis that understanding of climate policy by experts in one's own political party would moderate the effect of partisan social norms on climate policy support. Thus we test the informational mechanism of social influence, that individuals follow norms because they believe norms to convey valuable information relevant to evaluating a climate policy.

attributes.title: Context dependency in causal attributions in neuropsychiatry

q1.value: Context dependency in causal attributions in neuropsychiatry

q2.value: Jona Carmon, Moritz Bammel, Peter Brugger, Bigna Lenggenhager

q3.value:
Increasingly, brain correlates of mental disorders are researched. In consequence, correlations between observations of the brain or neural system and the behavior of mental disorders are left to interpretation. A recent study by Brugger et. al. has demonstrated that in the case of Xenomelia there is a unidirectional causal judgement of the correlation from brain to behavior (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.eurpsy.2018.03.005).

In this follow-up study, we hypothesize and test a context dependency of the causal judgement. Specifically, we are interested in the change of the causality vector according to different psychiatric and non-psychiatric conditions. Therefore, in addition to Xenomelia, we also investigate causal judgements for other contexts such as Receptive Aphasia and professional piano players.  

For more details see the attached document Pre_registering.pdf.

q4.value: See section 3 of the attached document Pre_registering.pdf.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

attributes.title: An investigation into the effects of fiction reading on critical thinking

q1.value: Effects of fiction, nonfiction and total reading over a two-week period on critical thinking test scores.

q3.value:
This study aims to investigate how different amounts of reading individuals engage in, what they read in terms of fiction and nonfiction, and how transported they are by reading, impacts their critical thinking. This study follows a previous observational pilot survey about reading and critical thinking disposition, and expands upon it by introducing experimental manipulation, and by addressing critical thinking skill rather than disposition. In this study, participants will be given a critical thinking test; they will be assigned fiction or nonfiction readings in the experimental conditions or no set readings in the control condition; they will be asked to complete a reading log over a two-week period; they will be given another version of the critical thinking test.

Existing research has shown that higher levels of reading are associated with a greater knowledge base (Stanovich and Cunningham, 1993). Furthermore, reading fiction has been shown to improve social skill (e.g. Mar, Oatley, Hirsh, dela Paz, and Peterson, 2006). Finally, fiction genre reading also plays a role in counterfactual thinking (Black, Capps, and Barnes, 2017). Reading is thought to have these effects due to the way that narrative transports the reader, and how they imagine and engage with the characters and scenes described. Experimental studies have shown that asking participants to read a fiction or a nonfiction text can result in different outcomes in empathy and theory of mind (Kidd and Castano, 2013), and that fiction reading can prompt pro-social behaviors (Johnson, 2012). We hypothesise that the knowledge, social skills, and counterfactual thinking gained through reading, especially fiction reading, will be deployed in critically evaluating texts. Therefore, we expect people who read more fiction over the experimental period to show greater critical thinking test score improvement than those who read less, or those who mainly read nonfiction.

q4.value:
H₀: Reading (quantity nor type) will have no significant association with critical thinking score either at t1, or with the difference between t1 and t2 score.

H₁: Higher reading engagement will have a significant association with higher baseline critical thinking score at t1.

H₂: Higher amounts of reading recorded over the reading log period will have a significant association with increases in critical thinking score from t1 to t2.

H₃: Higher amounts of fiction reading recorded over the reading log period will have a stronger association with increases in critical thinking score from t1 to t2 than nonfiction.

H₄: Narrative transportation will mediate the relationships predicted in H₂ and H₃.

H₄: Participants assigned to the fiction experimental group will have greater increases in their critical thinking test scores from t1 to t2 than either the nonfiction group or the control group.

Exploration: Reading some genres, such as Science Fiction and Fantasy, may correlate more strongly than other genre reading with greater increases in critical thinking score from t1 to t2. Nonfiction topic and type may likewise effect critical thinking score increases, with more fiction-like materials (such as biography) leading to greater increases. How engaged with, and how impacted by, participants are by the assigned texts may also have an impact on increases in critical thinking score. Being assigned to an experimental group that is congruous (i.e. fiction reader assigned fiction reading) or incongruous (i.e. nonfiction reader assigned fiction reading) may also have different effects. All of these are exploratory areas of interest.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value:
As the study will be completed online through a questionnaire, there will be no direct interaction between the researcher and the participants. No personal identifying data will be collected, and therefore the researcher will not be able to identify any individual participants.

Participants will know which experimental group they have been assigned to (i.e. fiction, nonfiction or control), as they will be assigned texts to read accordingly. 

Participants will be informed that the aim of the study is to investigate the relationship between what people and their critical thinking.

question.value:
This is a three-group, between-subjects (unpaired), repeated measures design. The study combines experimental and observational components. 

Experimental: Participants will be assigned readings, either 5 nonfiction texts for the nonfiction group, or 5 fiction texts for the fiction group, and asked to read these over the 2 week study period. The control group will not be given any assigned reading.

Observational: Participants will be asked to log their reading in a reading diary over the 2 week study period, with what they read being at their own discretion (aside from their assigned texts). They will also be given a critical thinking test before, and again after using a different test version, the 2 week diary period.

q9.value:
Block randomization will be used.

As our pilot study found that educational level and gender improved model fit when modelling critical thinking disposition and epistemological orientation, these two variables will be considered in the randomized blocking so as to balance them as much as possible, thus reducing their potential confounding effects. 

Participants will first express their interest in participating by completing an online form in which they will identify themselves as mainly fiction, or mainly nonfiction readers. They will also state their gender and their highest obtained educational level. 

First all interested participants will be grouped (fiction reading women with degrees, nonfiction reading women with degrees, fiction reading women without degrees, nonfiction reading women without degrees, fiction reading men with degrees, nonfiction reading men with degrees, fiction reading men without degrees, nonfiction reading men without degrees, other gender fiction readers, other gender nonfiction readers).

A random number generator will be used to selected participants from each group to take part in the study. 60 fiction readers, and 60 nonfiction readers will be selected. Fiction and nonfiction readers will be divided evenly between the fiction group (n=40), nonfiction group (n=40), and control group (n=40). This will yield 6 blocks (fiction readers assigned fiction, fiction readers assigned nonfiction, nonfiction readers assigned fiction, nonfiction readers assigned nonfiction, fiction readers in control group, nonfiction readers in control group), with the control variables of gender and education as evenly distributed across those 6 blocks as possible.

This procedure will enable us to balance our experimental groups, controlling for gender and educational level as potential confounding variables. The participants assigned to the different randomized blocks will then be contacted and invited to take part.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Self-selecting sampling will be used. Participants will be recruited online through social media. The study will also be advertised with posters and flyers in bookshops and in public libraries. To make the sample as diverse as possible, multiple venues will be used for advertisement.

Participants will first complete a basic form to register their interest in participating. In this form they will identify themselves as being mainly fiction, or mainly nonfiction readers, and also state their gender and educational level. This information will be used to select 120 participants into the randomized blocks for the study. Additional participants who registered their interest may be contacted to participate in the event that any participant withdraws from the study.

Participants must be 18 years old or older.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 120 (40 in each group). We will attempt to recruit interested participants in excess of the 120 target, so that we can invite additional participants in the event of anyone withdrawing from the study. No limit will therefore be set on the number of participants who can sign up as interested in participating, though no more than 120 will complete the study itself.

q14.value: A sample size of 120 participants (60 nonfiction readers and 60 fiction readers) was selected as this was deemed feasible in terms of recruitment, and fell within the limitation of available funding so each participant can be given a reward. Furthermore, using G*Power for a power analysis, assuming a medium effect size (f² 0.15) and a power of 80%, it is calculated that 77 participants are required for a multiple regression analysis of the measured variables upon critical thinking change. Thus rounding up to 80 allows for a base level of statistical power. 40 participants were added to form a control group.

q15.value:
No upper limit will be set on the number of participants who can express their interest in taking part and be put on the waiting list.

No more than 120 (40 in each group) participants will be invited to take part in the reading diary study. In the event of any participant withdrawing, another participant from the waiting list will be invited to participate, thus enabling us to reach out target participant number despite attrition.

question.value: Fiction vs Nonfiction assigned reading: We will assign 5 texts to each participant in one of the experimental groups and ask them to read these over the 2 week diary period. The fiction group will be assigned 5 fiction texts, and the nonfiction group will be assigned 5 nonfiction texts. These texts will be matched for total length, topics, and complexity. The control group will not be assigned any reading.

Covariates:
Age: open question. This is a Quantitative, interval, discrete variable.
Gender: open question. This is a Categorical, nominal variable.
Highest educational level attained: open question. This is a Categorical, ordinal variable.

Predictor variables:
Experimental group: assigned by the researcher: Fiction, Nonfiction or Control. This is a binary categorical variable.
Reader type: self-report from pre-study questionnaire. Fiction or nonfiction. This is a binary categorical variable.
Reading engagement: Participants will be asked to list their favourite authors, with a maximum of 10, but with no requirement to complete all 10 fields. The number of authors listed will be the reading engagement score. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable. 
Total reading amount: measured using the reading diary, this is the total number of all items logged over the 2 week diary period. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Fiction reading amount: measured using the reading diary, this is the total number of fiction items logged over the 2 week diary period. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Nonfiction reading amount: measured using the reading diary, this is the total number of nonfiction items logged over the 2 week diary period. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Total reading time: measured using the reading diary, this is the total number of minutes spent reading as reported by participants. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Fiction reading time: measured using the reading diary, this is the total number of minutes spent reading fiction as reported by participants. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Nonfiction reading time: measured using the reading diary, this is the total number of minutes spent reading nonfiction as reported by participants. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
(Moderator) Narrative transportation: for each item in the reading diary, participants will be asked to self-report how transported they were by each item read. This will be measured with a 5 point Likert scale from “not at all transported” to “completely transported”. This is a Categorical, ordinal variable.

Outcome variables:
Critical thinking t1 score: Measured using the International Critical Thinking Essay Test form A (ICTET-A) (The Foundation for Critical Thinking, 2019). Half of the participants will be randomly assigned text A, and half text B (with the two texts being matched for length and reading level).The ICTET takes 40-40mins to complete. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Critical thinking t2 score: Measured using the International Critical Thinking Essay Test form A (ICTET-A) (The Foundation for Critical Thinking, 2019). Participants who had text A at t1 will be given text B at t2, and vice versa, such that every participant has a different text to analyse from what they’ve already seen before. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Critical thinking change: the difference in critical thinking score between t1 and t2. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.

Exploratory variables:
Fiction genre: Both reading engagement, and fiction amount and time, can be broken down by genre (e.g. romance, science fiction, etc.) to explore possible effects. Doing so will yield individual genres as variables. These are quantitative, discrete, interval variables.
Nonfiction topic: Both reading engagement, and nonfiction amount and time, can be broken down by topic (e.g. biography, history, etc.) to explore possible effects. Doing so will yield individual topics as variables. These are quantitative, discrete, interval variables.
Reader type x Reader group: fiction reader assigned fiction texts; fiction reader assigned nonfiction texts; nonfiction reader assigned fiction texts; nonfiction reader assigned nonfiction texts. This is a categorical, nominal variable.
Some variables may be combined for exploratory analysis, for example highly transported reading time versus low transported time. However this will only be done exploration, not hypothesis testing.

Model 1: testing the effects of measured variables on baseline critical thinking scores.
Multiple regression analysis will be used to test the association between the measured variables prior to the reading log and t1 critical thinking test scores.

Model 2: testing effects of reading amounts on critical thinking change.
Hierarchical multiple regression will be used to partial out the covariates and test the effects for the predictor variables.

Model 3: testing effects of reading time on critical thinking change.
Hierarchical multiple regression will be used to partial out the covariates and test the effects for the predictor variables.

Model 4: testing mediation by narrative transportation on reading amount effecting critical thinking change.
Regression analysis will be used to compare the effect of fiction reading amount on critical thinking change, with and without narrative transportation as a mediator. Likewise for nonfiction reading amount.
Model-based causal mediation analysis will be performed (using the 'mediation' package for R), with bootstrapped confidence level estimation, to calculate the average causal mediation effect (Tingley, Yamamoto, Hirose, Keele, and Imai, 2014).

Model 5: testing mediation by narrative transportation on reading time effecting critical thinking change.
Regression analysis will be used to compare the effect of fiction reading time on critical thinking change, with and without narrative transportation as a mediator. Likewise for nonfiction reading time.
Model-based causal mediation analysis will be performed (using the 'mediation' package for R), with bootstrapped confidence level estimation, to calculate the average causal mediation effect (Tingley et al, 2014).

q20.value:
Highest educational level attained: measured with an open question. This is a Categorical, ordinal variable. If possible, answers will be re-coded to the categories of equivalent educational level in the 2011 UK Census. However, in my pilot study this grouping did not fit the data well, as my participants were highly educated and therefore segmenting the higher education levels into smaller categories, and collapsing the lower education levels into fewer categories, better reflected the data. Depending on the distribution of education in the sample for this study, education categories may need to deviate from the UK Census in this way. For regression analysis, education level will be dummy coded with the lowest (GCSE or equivalent) as the reference category.

Narrative transportation: this is a categorical, ordinal variable measured with Likert scales. First, the mean score of each participant across the 2 week diary period will be calculated. These mean scores will then be used to group participants into categories, using the mean and SD as cut-off points. This will create 4 categories of NT ranging from low to high. For regression analysis, NT level will be dummy coded with ‘low’ as the reference category.

Gender: measured with an open question. This is a nominal variable. Participants will have the option of self-identifying their gender or inputting ‘prefer not to say’. Depending on participant inputs, categories of ‘male’ ‘female’ ‘neither’ ‘unstated’ will be used, with ‘female’ being the reference category.

q21.value: Two tailed tests will be used. The standard p < .05 criteria will be used to determine if results are significantly different from the null hypothesis prediction.

q22.value:
Participants who enter an age value of less than 18 will be excluded. 

Participants who complete less than 80% of the diary days (i.e. those who miss more than 3 days of the diary) will also be excluded. Marking a day as having no reading to log does not constitute missing that day.

q23.value:
If a participant does not complete either CT test, they will be excluded from analysis. Missing more than 3 days of the diary will also result in exclusion. 

Mean imputation will be used to replace quantitative reading diary missing data such as reading time.

q24.value:
Although the main focus of this study is to compare individual participants (i.e. between-subjects), and also to look at fiction/nonfiction/control assigned text groups (i.e. between groups), the groups will be comprised of half participants who identified themselves as fiction readers and half nonfiction readers. Therefore the difference between assigned to a congruous or incongruous group to one’s prior reader interests will be tested as an exploratory avenue that may have an effect on the outcome variables.

Additionally, genre and topic of the fiction and nonfiction texts read by participants over the diary period will also be assessed for any effect on the outcome variables as an exploratory analysis.

q25.value:
References

Black, J. E., Capps, S. C., and Barnes, J. L. (2017). Fiction, genre exposure, and moral reality. Psychology of Aesthetics, Creativity, and the Arts. https://doi.org/10.1037/aca0000116
Johnson, D. R. (2012). Transportation into a story increases empathy, prosocial behavior, and perceptual bias toward fearful expressions. Personality and Individual Differences, 52(2), 150–155. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2011.10.005
Kidd, D. C., and Castano, E. (2013). Reading literary fiction improves theory of mind. Science, 342(6156), 377–380. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1239918
Mar, R. A., Oatley, K., Hirsh, J., dela Paz, J., and Peterson, J. B. (2006). Bookworms versus nerds: Exposure to fiction versus non-fiction, divergent associations with social ability, and the simulation of fictional social worlds. Journal of Research in Personality, 40, 694–712. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jrp.2005.08.002
Stanovich, K. E., and Cunningham, A. E. (1993). Where does knowledge come from? Specific associations between print exposure and information acquisition. Journal of Educational Psychology, 85, 211–229.
The Foundation for Critical Thinking. (2019). International Critical Thinking Test. Retrieved from https://www.criticalthinking.org/pages/international-critical-thinking-test/619
Tingley, D., Yamamoto, T., Hirose, K., Keele, L., and Imai, K. (2014). mediation: R package for causal mediation analysis. Journal of Statistical Software, 59(5). https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v059.i05

registration_responses.q1: Effects of fiction, nonfiction and total reading over a two-week period on critical thinking test scores.
registration_responses.q3:

This study follows a previous observational pilot survey about reading and critical thinking disposition, and expands upon it by introducing experimental manipulation, and by addressing critical thinking skill rather than disposition. In this study, participants will be given a critical thinking test; they will be assigned fiction or nonfiction readings in the experimental conditions or no set readings in the control condition; they will be asked to complete a reading log over a two-week period; they will be given another version of the critical thinking test.

Existing research has shown that higher levels of reading are associated with a greater knowledge base (Stanovich and Cunningham, 1993). Furthermore, reading fiction has been shown to improve social skill (e.g. Mar, Oatley, Hirsh, dela Paz, and Peterson, 2006). Finally, fiction genre reading also plays a role in counterfactual thinking (Black, Capps, and Barnes, 2017). Reading is thought to have these effects due to the way that narrative transports the reader, and how they imagine and engage with the characters and scenes described. Experimental studies have shown that asking participants to read a fiction or a nonfiction text can result in different outcomes in empathy and theory of mind (Kidd and Castano, 2013), and that fiction reading can prompt pro-social behaviors (Johnson, 2012). We hypothesise that the knowledge, social skills, and counterfactual thinking gained through reading, especially fiction reading, will be deployed in critically evaluating texts. Therefore, we expect people who read more fiction over the experimental period to show greater critical thinking test score improvement than those who read less, or those who mainly read nonfiction.
registration_responses.q4:
H₀: Reading (quantity nor type) will have no significant association with critical thinking score either at t1, or with the difference between t1 and t2 score.

H₁: Higher reading engagement will have a significant association with higher baseline critical thinking score at t1.

H₂: Higher amounts of reading recorded over the reading log period will have a significant association with increases in critical thinking score from t1 to t2.

H₃: Higher amounts of fiction reading recorded over the reading log period will have a stronger association with increases in critical thinking score from t1 to t2 than nonfiction.

H₄: Narrative transportation will mediate the relationships predicted in H₂ and H₃.

H₄: Participants assigned to the fiction experimental group will have greater increases in their critical thinking test scores from t1 to t2 than either the nonfiction group or the control group.

Exploration: Reading some genres, such as Science Fiction and Fantasy, may correlate more strongly than other genre reading with greater increases in critical thinking score from t1 to t2. Nonfiction topic and type may likewise effect critical thinking score increases, with more fiction-like materials (such as biography) leading to greater increases. How engaged with, and how impacted by, participants are by the assigned texts may also have an impact on increases in critical thinking score. Being assigned to an experimental group that is congruous (i.e. fiction reader assigned fiction reading) or incongruous (i.e. nonfiction reader assigned fiction reading) may also have different effects. All of these are exploratory areas of interest.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q7:
As the study will be completed online through a questionnaire, there will be no direct interaction between the researcher and the participants. No personal identifying data will be collected, and therefore the researcher will not be able to identify any individual participants.

Participants will know which experimental group they have been assigned to (i.e. fiction, nonfiction or control), as they will be assigned texts to read accordingly. 

Participants will be informed that the aim of the study is to investigate the relationship between what people and their critical thinking.
registration_responses.q9:
Block randomization will be used.

As our pilot study found that educational level and gender improved model fit when modelling critical thinking disposition and epistemological orientation, these two variables will be considered in the randomized blocking so as to balance them as much as possible, thus reducing their potential confounding effects. 

Participants will first express their interest in participating by completing an online form in which they will identify themselves as mainly fiction, or mainly nonfiction readers. They will also state their gender and their highest obtained educational level. 

First all interested participants will be grouped (fiction reading women with degrees, nonfiction reading women with degrees, fiction reading women without degrees, nonfiction reading women without degrees, fiction reading men with degrees, nonfiction reading men with degrees, fiction reading men without degrees, nonfiction reading men without degrees, other gender fiction readers, other gender nonfiction readers).

A random number generator will be used to selected participants from each group to take part in the study. 60 fiction readers, and 60 nonfiction readers will be selected. Fiction and nonfiction readers will be divided evenly between the fiction group (n=40), nonfiction group (n=40), and control group (n=40). This will yield 6 blocks (fiction readers assigned fiction, fiction readers assigned nonfiction, nonfiction readers assigned fiction, nonfiction readers assigned nonfiction, fiction readers in control group, nonfiction readers in control group), with the control variables of gender and education as evenly distributed across those 6 blocks as possible.

This procedure will enable us to balance our experimental groups, controlling for gender and educational level as potential confounding variables. The participants assigned to the different randomized blocks will then be contacted and invited to take part.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Our target sample size is 120 (40 in each group). We will attempt to recruit interested participants in excess of the 120 target, so that we can invite additional participants in the event of anyone withdrawing from the study. No limit will therefore be set on the number of participants who can sign up as interested in participating, though no more than 120 will complete the study itself.
registration_responses.q14: A sample size of 120 participants (60 nonfiction readers and 60 fiction readers) was selected as this was deemed feasible in terms of recruitment, and fell within the limitation of available funding so each participant can be given a reward. Furthermore, using G*Power for a power analysis, assuming a medium effect size (f² 0.15) and a power of 80%, it is calculated that 77 participants are required for a multiple regression analysis of the measured variables upon critical thinking change. Thus rounding up to 80 allows for a base level of statistical power. 40 participants were added to form a control group.
registration_responses.q15:
No upper limit will be set on the number of participants who can express their interest in taking part and be put on the waiting list.

No more than 120 (40 in each group) participants will be invited to take part in the reading diary study. In the event of any participant withdrawing, another participant from the waiting list will be invited to participate, thus enabling us to reach out target participant number despite attrition.
registration_responses.q20:
Highest educational level attained: measured with an open question. This is a Categorical, ordinal variable. If possible, answers will be re-coded to the categories of equivalent educational level in the 2011 UK Census. However, in my pilot study this grouping did not fit the data well, as my participants were highly educated and therefore segmenting the higher education levels into smaller categories, and collapsing the lower education levels into fewer categories, better reflected the data. Depending on the distribution of education in the sample for this study, education categories may need to deviate from the UK Census in this way. For regression analysis, education level will be dummy coded with the lowest (GCSE or equivalent) as the reference category.

Narrative transportation: this is a categorical, ordinal variable measured with Likert scales. First, the mean score of each participant across the 2 week diary period will be calculated. These mean scores will then be used to group participants into categories, using the mean and SD as cut-off points. This will create 4 categories of NT ranging from low to high. For regression analysis, NT level will be dummy coded with ‘low’ as the reference category.

Gender: measured with an open question. This is a nominal variable. Participants will have the option of self-identifying their gender or inputting ‘prefer not to say’. Depending on participant inputs, categories of ‘male’ ‘female’ ‘neither’ ‘unstated’ will be used, with ‘female’ being the reference category.
registration_responses.q21: Two tailed tests will be used. The standard p < .05 criteria will be used to determine if results are significantly different from the null hypothesis prediction.
registration_responses.q22:
Participants who enter an age value of less than 18 will be excluded. 

Participants who complete less than 80% of the diary days (i.e. those who miss more than 3 days of the diary) will also be excluded. Marking a day as having no reading to log does not constitute missing that day.
registration_responses.q23:
If a participant does not complete either CT test, they will be excluded from analysis. Missing more than 3 days of the diary will also result in exclusion. 

Mean imputation will be used to replace quantitative reading diary missing data such as reading time.
registration_responses.q24:
Although the main focus of this study is to compare individual participants (i.e. between-subjects), and also to look at fiction/nonfiction/control assigned text groups (i.e. between groups), the groups will be comprised of half participants who identified themselves as fiction readers and half nonfiction readers. Therefore the difference between assigned to a congruous or incongruous group to one’s prior reader interests will be tested as an exploratory avenue that may have an effect on the outcome variables.

Additionally, genre and topic of the fiction and nonfiction texts read by participants over the diary period will also be assessed for any effect on the outcome variables as an exploratory analysis.
registration_responses.q25:
References

Black, J. E., Capps, S. C., and Barnes, J. L. (2017). Fiction, genre exposure, and moral reality. Psychology of Aesthetics, Creativity, and the Arts. https://doi.org/10.1037/aca0000116
Johnson, D. R. (2012). Transportation into a story increases empathy, prosocial behavior, and perceptual bias toward fearful expressions. Personality and Individual Differences, 52(2), 150–155. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2011.10.005
Kidd, D. C., and Castano, E. (2013). Reading literary fiction improves theory of mind. Science, 342(6156), 377–380. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1239918
Mar, R. A., Oatley, K., Hirsh, J., dela Paz, J., and Peterson, J. B. (2006). Bookworms versus nerds: Exposure to fiction versus non-fiction, divergent associations with social ability, and the simulation of fictional social worlds. Journal of Research in Personality, 40, 694–712. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jrp.2005.08.002
Stanovich, K. E., and Cunningham, A. E. (1993). Where does knowledge come from? Specific associations between print exposure and information acquisition. Journal of Educational Psychology, 85, 211–229.
The Foundation for Critical Thinking. (2019). International Critical Thinking Test. Retrieved from https://www.criticalthinking.org/pages/international-critical-thinking-test/619
Tingley, D., Yamamoto, T., Hirose, K., Keele, L., and Imai, K. (2014). mediation: R package for causal mediation analysis. Journal of Statistical Software, 59(5). https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v059.i05
registration_responses.q8.question:
This is a three-group, between-subjects (unpaired), repeated measures design. The study combines experimental and observational components. 

Experimental: Participants will be assigned readings, either 5 nonfiction texts for the nonfiction group, or 5 fiction texts for the fiction group, and asked to read these over the 2 week study period. The control group will not be given any assigned reading.

Observational: Participants will be asked to log their reading in a reading diary over the 2 week study period, with what they read being at their own discretion (aside from their assigned texts). They will also be given a critical thinking test before, and again after using a different test version, the 2 week diary period.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Self-selecting sampling will be used. Participants will be recruited online through social media. The study will also be advertised with posters and flyers in bookshops and in public libraries. To make the sample as diverse as possible, multiple venues will be used for advertisement.

Participants will first complete a basic form to register their interest in participating. In this form they will identify themselves as being mainly fiction, or mainly nonfiction readers, and also state their gender and educational level. This information will be used to select 120 participants into the randomized blocks for the study. Additional participants who registered their interest may be contacted to participate in the event that any participant withdraws from the study.

Participants must be 18 years old or older.
registration_responses.q16.question: Fiction vs Nonfiction assigned reading: We will assign 5 texts to each participant in one of the experimental groups and ask them to read these over the 2 week diary period. The fiction group will be assigned 5 fiction texts, and the nonfiction group will be assigned 5 nonfiction texts. These texts will be matched for total length, topics, and complexity. The control group will not be assigned any reading.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Covariates:
Age: open question. This is a Quantitative, interval, discrete variable.
Gender: open question. This is a Categorical, nominal variable.
Highest educational level attained: open question. This is a Categorical, ordinal variable.

Predictor variables:
Experimental group: assigned by the researcher: Fiction, Nonfiction or Control. This is a binary categorical variable.
Reader type: self-report from pre-study questionnaire. Fiction or nonfiction. This is a binary categorical variable.
Reading engagement: Participants will be asked to list their favourite authors, with a maximum of 10, but with no requirement to complete all 10 fields. The number of authors listed will be the reading engagement score. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable. 
Total reading amount: measured using the reading diary, this is the total number of all items logged over the 2 week diary period. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Fiction reading amount: measured using the reading diary, this is the total number of fiction items logged over the 2 week diary period. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Nonfiction reading amount: measured using the reading diary, this is the total number of nonfiction items logged over the 2 week diary period. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Total reading time: measured using the reading diary, this is the total number of minutes spent reading as reported by participants. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Fiction reading time: measured using the reading diary, this is the total number of minutes spent reading fiction as reported by participants. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Nonfiction reading time: measured using the reading diary, this is the total number of minutes spent reading nonfiction as reported by participants. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
(Moderator) Narrative transportation: for each item in the reading diary, participants will be asked to self-report how transported they were by each item read. This will be measured with a 5 point Likert scale from “not at all transported” to “completely transported”. This is a Categorical, ordinal variable.

Outcome variables:
Critical thinking t1 score: Measured using the International Critical Thinking Essay Test form A (ICTET-A) (The Foundation for Critical Thinking, 2019). Half of the participants will be randomly assigned text A, and half text B (with the two texts being matched for length and reading level).The ICTET takes 40-40mins to complete. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Critical thinking t2 score: Measured using the International Critical Thinking Essay Test form A (ICTET-A) (The Foundation for Critical Thinking, 2019). Participants who had text A at t1 will be given text B at t2, and vice versa, such that every participant has a different text to analyse from what they’ve already seen before. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.
Critical thinking change: the difference in critical thinking score between t1 and t2. This is a quantitative, discrete, interval variable.

Exploratory variables:
Fiction genre: Both reading engagement, and fiction amount and time, can be broken down by genre (e.g. romance, science fiction, etc.) to explore possible effects. Doing so will yield individual genres as variables. These are quantitative, discrete, interval variables.
Nonfiction topic: Both reading engagement, and nonfiction amount and time, can be broken down by topic (e.g. biography, history, etc.) to explore possible effects. Doing so will yield individual topics as variables. These are quantitative, discrete, interval variables.
Reader type x Reader group: fiction reader assigned fiction texts; fiction reader assigned nonfiction texts; nonfiction reader assigned fiction texts; nonfiction reader assigned nonfiction texts. This is a categorical, nominal variable.
registration_responses.q18.question: Some variables may be combined for exploratory analysis, for example highly transported reading time versus low transported time. However this will only be done exploration, not hypothesis testing.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Model 1: testing the effects of measured variables on baseline critical thinking scores.
Multiple regression analysis will be used to test the association between the measured variables prior to the reading log and t1 critical thinking test scores.

Model 2: testing effects of reading amounts on critical thinking change.
Hierarchical multiple regression will be used to partial out the covariates and test the effects for the predictor variables.

Model 3: testing effects of reading time on critical thinking change.
Hierarchical multiple regression will be used to partial out the covariates and test the effects for the predictor variables.

Model 4: testing mediation by narrative transportation on reading amount effecting critical thinking change.
Regression analysis will be used to compare the effect of fiction reading amount on critical thinking change, with and without narrative transportation as a mediator. Likewise for nonfiction reading amount.
Model-based causal mediation analysis will be performed (using the 'mediation' package for R), with bootstrapped confidence level estimation, to calculate the average causal mediation effect (Tingley, Yamamoto, Hirose, Keele, and Imai, 2014).

Model 5: testing mediation by narrative transportation on reading time effecting critical thinking change.
Regression analysis will be used to compare the effect of fiction reading time on critical thinking change, with and without narrative transportation as a mediator. Likewise for nonfiction reading time.
Model-based causal mediation analysis will be performed (using the 'mediation' package for R), with bootstrapped confidence level estimation, to calculate the average causal mediation effect (Tingley et al, 2014).
